articles.title: Crimean War
articles.context: Greece played a peripheral role in the war. When Russia attacked the Ottoman Empire in 1853, King Otto of Greece saw an opportunity to expand North and South into Ottoman areas that had large Greek Christian majorities. However, Greece did not coordinate its plans with Russia, did not declare war, and received no outside military or financial support. Greece, an Orthodox nation, had considerable support in Russia, but the Russian government decided it was too dangerous to help Greece expand its holdings.:32â€“40 When the Russians invaded the Principalities, the Ottoman forces were tied down so Greece invaded Thessaly and Epirus. To block further Greek moves, the British and French occupied the main Greek port at Piraeus from April 1854 to February 1857, and effectively neutralized the Greek army. Greeks, gambling on a Russian victory, incited the large-scale Epirus Revolt of 1854 as well as uprisings in Crete. The insurrections were failures that were easily crushed by the Ottoman army. Greece was not invited to the peace conference and made no gains out of the war.:139 The frustrated Greek leadership blamed the King for failing to take advantage of the situation; his popularity plunged and he was later forced to abdicate.

Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
History of India
The 7th and 6th centuries BC witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads. Upanishads form the theoretical basis of classical Hinduism and are known as Vedanta (conclusion of the Vedas). The older Upanishads launched attacks of increasing intensity on the ritual. Anyone who worships a divinity other than the Self is called a domestic animal of the gods in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. The Mundaka launches the most scathing attack on the ritual by comparing those who value sacrifice with an unsafe boat that is endlessly overtaken by old age and death.

articles.title: Memory
articles.context: Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewersâ€™ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event â€“ those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

completions.text:
In reality, human memory operates quite differently from that of a recording device. The chemical processes that occur during the formation and preservation of memories are continuously evolving, encompassing several stages within a timeframe ranging from mere seconds to an entire lifetime. Interestingly, scientific research has revealed that our memories are not solely inert recordings but actively constructed based on the moment of encoding and recall. For instance, in a classic study by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974), participants viewed a film depicting a car collision. Later, when asked about the scene, those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" reported higher speeds compared to those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Moreover, a week after the viewing, participants who had been asked the more dramatic question ("smashed") were more likely to believe they had seen broken glass in the film, even though no such element was present. This demonstrates how question wording can distort memory construction. Importantly, these distortions led subjects to create different interpretations of the event, where the more sensational query caused them to remember a more severe car crash than originally witnessedâ€”a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

Another way to rephrase the passage could be:

Human memory's workings differ significantly from those of recording devices. The chemical processes underlying the creation and retention of memories are constantly shifting and involve multiple phases spanning from brief moments to lifelong periods. Experiments reveal that people's memories are essentially reconstructed during both encoding and retrieval stages. A notable study by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) illustrates this phenomenon through a traffic accident film scenario. Participants were queried differently about the event, with some asked about a more violent collision ("smashed") than others ("hit"). Subsequent inquiries revealed that those presented with the more dramatic term ("smashed") recalled more damage to the scene, including broken glass, which did not actually exist. Crucially, the way these questions were framed affected how memories were constructed, leading individuals to perceive a more intense accident than actually witnessed. This alteration in memory content is referred to as the misinformation effect.

Yet another version could read:

Contrary to popular belief, human memory doesn't function as an exact recorder. The biochemical processes that govern memory acquisition and preservation are highly fluid and can be divided into various stages extending from seconds to a lifetime. Scientific investigations have shown that memories are actually reconstructed during both the initial encoding and subsequent recall stages. A well-known experiment by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) provided evidence of this reconstruction process. Subjects were shown a video of a car accident and later questioned about it. The terms used in the questions ("smashed" vs. "hit") influenced the subjects' perceptions of the event. One week later, those who were initially asked the more expressive question ("smashed") were more likely to recall seeing broken glass in the film, even though it didn't appear in the footage. This demonstrates that the phrasing of questions can alter memories, creating a discrepancy between how events were witnessed and how they are rememberedâ€”this is termed the misinformation effect.

Passage:
Memory
Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research has revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people were instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those who were asked, "How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they have seen broken glass in the film, those who had been asked the question with smashed were twice more likely to report that they have seen broken glass than those who had been asked the question with hit. There was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewersâ€™ memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event â€“ those who were asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they had actually seen. The findings of this experiment were replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people were provided with misleading information they tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

Antarctica's Natural Resources
Despite the discovery of resources such as coal, hydrocarbons, iron ore, platinum, copper, chromium, nickel, gold, and other minerals, they have been found in insufficient quantities for commercial exploitation. This is due to the 1991 Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty that prevents a resource rush. In 1998, a landmark agreement was struck to institute an indefinite ban on mining, subject to a review in 2048, further restricting economic development and exploitation. Currently, the main economic activity involves fishing and offshore trading, with Antarctic fisheries in the 2000-01 season landing 112,934 tonnes of fish.

The Limitations of Antarctic Resources
While coal, hydrocarbons, iron ore, platinum, copper, chromium, nickel, gold, and other minerals have been identified in Antarctica, they lack in quantity for economic exploration. In 1998, a breakthrough agreement was reached to impose an indefinite ban on mining, which is subject to evaluation in 2048. In 1998, an agreement was reached to impose an indefinite ban on mining, subject to a reassessment in 2048, further limiting economic development and exploitation. But, unfortunately, everyone just stuck with Herschel for Uranus and Neptune for the new one.

The recent discovery of a new planet in the solar system has led to debates regarding its naming. One prominent claimant to the right of naming this new celestial body was Urbain Le Verrier, who proposed the name Neptune. However, Le Verrier's suggestion faced significant opposition from astronomers outside of France. Consequently, the decision was made to employ an alternate nomenclature, specifically the designation "Herschel" for the planet previously known as Uranus, in honor of Sir William Herschel, the original discoverer. Meanwhile, the newly identified planet was christened "Le Verrier," reflecting the efforts of the French scientist who spearheaded the discovery. It is worth noting that while many celestial objects have been associated with multiple names over time, Herschel remains the widely accepted moniker for Uranus, whereas Le Verrier is utilized exclusively for this novel addition to the planetary family.

As a result, alternative proposals emerged, most notably the enduring popularity of Herschel for Uranus. articles.title: Brain
articles.context: Once a neuron is in place, it extends dendrites and an axon into the area around it. Axons, because they commonly extend a great distance from the cell body and need to reach specific targets, grow in a particularly complex way. The tip of a growing axon consists of a blob of protoplasm called a growth cone, studded with chemical receptors. These receptors sense the local environment, causing the growth cone to be attracted or repelled by various cellular elements, and thus to be pulled in a particular direction at each point along its path. The result of this pathfinding process is that the growth cone navigates through the brain until it reaches its destination area, where other chemical cues cause it to begin generating synapses. Considering the entire brain, thousands of genes create products that influence axonal pathfinding.

Capital punishment in the United States
James Liebman, a professor of law at Columbia Law School, stated in 1996 that his study found that when habeas corpus petitions in death penalty cases were traced from conviction to completion of the case that there was "a 40 percent success rate in all capital cases from 1978 to 1995." Similarly, a study by Ronald Tabak in a law review article puts the success rate in habeas corpus cases involving death row inmates even higher, finding that between "1976 and 1991, approximately 47 percent of the habeas petitions filed by death row inmates were granted." The different numbers are largely definitional, rather than substantive. Freedam's statistics looks at the percentage of all death penalty cases reversed, while the others look only at cases not reversed prior to habeas corpus review.

articles.title: Electric motor
articles.context: An advantage of the universal motor is that AC supplies may be used on motors which have some characteristics more common in DC motors, specifically high starting torque and very compact design if high running speeds are used. The negative aspect is the maintenance and short life problems caused by the commutator. Such motors are used in devices such as food mixers and power tools which are used only intermittently, and often have high starting-torque demands. Multiple taps on the field coil provide (imprecise) stepped speed control. Household blenders that advertise many speeds frequently combine a field coil with several taps and a diode that can be inserted in series with the motor (causing the motor to run on half-wave rectified AC). Universal motors also lend themselves to electronic speed control and, as such, are an ideal choice for devices like domestic washing machines. The motor can be used to agitate the drum (both forwards and in reverse) by switching the field winding with respect to the armature.

Multiple taps on the field coil provide (imprecise) stepped speed control. Household blenders that advertise many speeds frequently combine a field coil with several taps and a diode that can be inserted in series with the motor (causing the motor to run on half-wave rectified AC). Universal motors also lend themselves to electronic speed control and, as such, are an ideal choice for devices like domestic washing machines. The motor can be used to agitate the drum (both forwards and in reverse) by switching the field winding with respect to the armature.

Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Dwight D. Eisenhower
His parents set aside specific times at breakfast and at dinner for daily family Bible reading. Chores were regularly assigned and rotated among all the children, and misbehavior was met with unequivocal discipline, usually from David. His mother, previously a member (with David) of the River Brethren sect of the Mennonites, joined the International Bible Students Association, later known as Jehovah's Witnesses. The Eisenhower home served as the local meeting hall from 1896 to 1915, though Eisenhower never joined the International Bible Students. His later decision to attend West Point saddened his mother, who felt that warfare was "rather wicked," but she did not overrule him. While speaking of himself in 1948, Eisenhower said he was "one of the most deeply religious men I know" though unattached to any "sect or organization". He was baptized in the Presbyterian Church in 1953.

articles.title: Pacific War
articles.context: The Battle of Leyte Gulf was arguably the largest naval battle in history and was the largest naval battle of World War II. It was a series of four distinct engagements fought off the Philippine island of Leyte from 23 to 26 October 1944. Leyte Gulf featured the largest battleships ever built, was the last time in history that battleships engaged each other, and was also notable as the first time that kamikaze aircraft were used. Allied victory in the Philippine Sea established Allied air and sea superiority in the western Pacific. Nimitz favored blockading the Philippines and landing on Formosa. This would give the Allies control of the sea routes to Japan from southern Asia, cutting off substantial Japanese garrisons. MacArthur favored an invasion of the Philippines, which also lay across the supply lines to Japan. Roosevelt adjudicated in favor of the Philippines. Meanwhile, Japanese Combined Fleet Chief Toyoda Soemu prepared four plans to cover all Allied offensive scenarios. On 12 October Nimitz launched a carrier raid against Formosa to make sure that planes based there could not intervene in the landings on Leyte. Toyoda put Plan Sho-2 into effect, launching a series of air attacks against the U.S. carriers. However the Japanese lost 600 planes in three days, leaving them without air cover.

articles.title: Tuberculosis
articles.context: In 15â€“20% of active cases, the infection spreads outside the lungs, causing other kinds of TB. These are collectively denoted as "extrapulmonary tuberculosis". Extrapulmonary TB occurs more commonly in immunosuppressed persons and young children. In those with HIV, this occurs in more than 50% of cases. Notable extrapulmonary infection sites include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), the central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), the lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), the genitourinary system (in urogenital tuberculosis), and the bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine), among others. When it spreads to the bones, it is also known as "osseous tuberculosis", a form of osteomyelitis. Sometimes, bursting of a tubercular abscess through skin results in tuberculous ulcer. An ulcer originating from nearby infected lymph nodes is painless, slowly enlarging and has an appearance of "wash leather". A potentially more serious, widespread form of TB is called "disseminated tuberculosis", also known as miliary tuberculosis. Miliary TB makes up about 10% of extrapulmonary cases.

Certainly! Here are three different ways to rewrite the passage:

1. **Epidemiology of TB**:
   - Approximately 15 to 20 percent of active tuberculosis (TB) cases experience the spread of the infection beyond the lungs, leading to extrapulmonary TB. This type of TB predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals and young children. Among individuals with HIV, the prevalence of extrapulmonary TB is as high as 50 percent. Common sites of extrapulmonary involvement include the pleura, central nervous system, lymphatic system, genitourinary system, and bones and joints. When TB spreads to the bones, it is termed osseous tuberculosis, a form of osteomyelitis. Bursting through the skin can result in tuberculous ulcers, characterized by a painless, slowly enlarging, and "wash leather"-like appearance. A broader, more severe form of TB, known as disseminated TB or miliary TB, accounts for about 10 percent of extrapulmonary cases.

2. **Extravascular Tuberculosis**:
   - Extravascular tuberculosis, affecting approximately 15 to 20 percent of all active TB cases, manifests when the infection extends outside the lungs. Characterized as extrapulmonary TB, it disproportionately impacts immunosuppressed patients and young children, with a significant 50 percent prevalence among those with HIV. Common sites of extrapulmonary TB include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), genitourinary system (in urogenital TB), and bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine), among others. This type of TB, especially when it affects bones, is called "osseous tuberculosis," a form of osteomyelitis. When the infection breaks through the skin, it can result in a painless, slowly enlarging tuberculous ulcer. Notably, in about 10 percent of cases, TB spreads widely, known as disseminated TB or miliary TB.

3. **Nonpulmonary Tuberculosis**:
   - In roughly 15 to 20 percent of all active TB cases, the infection spreads beyond the lungs, resulting in a condition known as nonpulmonary or extrapulmonary TB. This form of TB predominantly affects individuals with compromised immunity, including young children and those with HIV, where it occurs in up to 50 percent of cases. Sites of nonpulmonary involvement include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), central nervous system (in tuberculous meningitis), lymphatic system (in scrofula), genitourinary system (in urogenital TB), and bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine). In particular, when TB affects the bones, it is referred to as osseous tuberculosis, a form of osteomyelitis. A tuberculous ulcer can develop from a ruptured TB abscess, typically painless, slowly expanding, and exhibiting a "wash leather" appearance. Widespread dissemination of TB, also known as miliary TB, accounts for about 10 percent of nonpulmonary cases.

Once upon a time, in a small country called the Saarland, there was a big decision to be made. 

The decision was about whether the Saarland should become an independent nation, meaning it would run its own affairs and make its own choices.

Passage:
Pope Paul VI
In 1916, he entered the seminary to become a Roman Catholic priest. He was ordained priest on 29 May 1920 in Brescia and celebrated his first Holy Mass in Brescia in the Basilica of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Montini concluded his studies in Milan with a doctorate in Canon Law in the same year. Afterwards he studied at the Gregorian University, the University of Rome La Sapienza and, at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo at the Accademia dei Nobili Ecclesiastici. At the age of twenty-five, again at the request of Giuseppe Pizzardo, Montini entered the Secretariat of State in 1922, where he worked under Pizzardo together with Francesco Borgongini-Duca, Alfredo Ottaviani, Carlo Grano, Domenico Tardini and Francis Spellman. Consequently, he spent not a day as a parish priest. In 1925 he helped found the publishing house Morcelliana in Brescia, focused on promoting a 'Christian inspired culture'.

## Awnings

### Manually Controlled Awnings
Manual awnings are operated by hand. They can be raised or lowered by a person, giving them the flexibility to adjust the amount of shade they provide. Manual awnings are common in older buildings and can be a cost-effective solution.

### Manually Controlled Retractable Awnings
These awnings retract with the help of cords. They can be opened and closed by pulling on the cords, which is an easy and convenient way to adjust the amount of shade they provide. This type of awning can be found on many different types of buildings and can be used to create a modern and stylish exterior.

articles.title: Asthma
articles.context: The evidence for the effectiveness of measures to prevent the development of asthma is weak. Some show promise including: limiting smoke exposure both in utero and after delivery, breastfeeding, and increased exposure to daycare or large families but none are well supported enough to be recommended for this indication. Early pet exposure may be useful. Results from exposure to pets at other times are inconclusive and it is only recommended that pets be removed from the home if a person has allergic symptoms to said pet. Dietary restrictions during pregnancy or when breast feeding have not been found to be effective and thus are not recommended. Reducing or eliminating compounds known to sensitive people from the work place may be effective. It is not clear if annual influenza vaccinations effects the risk of exacerbations. Immunization; however, is recommended by the World Health Organization. Smoking bans are effective in decreasing exacerbations of asthma.

completions.text:
In a bid to prevent the onset of asthma, several preventive measures have been explored, and while some indications suggest a beneficial effect, a lack of robust evidence often hinders the endorsement of such strategies. Among these, efforts to limit prenatal and postnatal exposure to smoke, promote breastfeeding, and enhance contact with daycare settings or large family units have demonstrated potential. Nonetheless, none of these interventions have reached the threshold of definitive support, thereby discouraging their widespread implementation as preventive measures. Notably, the removal of pets from the domestic environment presents as a plausible avenue, particularly for those sensitive to pet allergens, though the correlation remains ambiguous, and petlessness is advised only upon experiencing allergic symptoms to the animal. The adoption of dietary restrictions throughout pregnancy or the period of breastfeeding has not been found to be advantageous, consequently, such practices are not recommended.

The promotion of preventive measures for the development of asthma has proven to be fraught with uncertainty, with a notable absence of definitive evidence substantiating the efficacy of many interventions. It is, however, a recognized finding that reducing or eliminating potential allergens from the workplace can be beneficial in managing the condition. Moreover, annual flu vaccinations have been shown to have some impact on exacerbations of asthma, though their effect remains unproven and further investigation is warranted. Notably, the World Health Organization recommends the yearly influenza vaccination, further endorsing its potential benefits. Lastly, it is strongly recommended that individuals with asthma-related sensitivities take appropriate steps to limit or remove smoke exposure, both during pregnancy and after delivery, and to actively consider removing pets from the household environment if they are displaying symptoms of pet allergens.

articles.context: After secession, some North Carolinians refused to support the Confederacy. Some of the yeoman farmers in the state's mountains and western Piedmont region remained neutral during the Civil War, while some covertly supported the Union cause during the conflict. Approximately 2,000 North Carolinians from western North Carolina enlisted in the Union Army and fought for the North in the war. Two additional Union Army regiments were raised in the coastal areas of the state, which were occupied by Union forces in 1862 and 1863. Numerous slaves escaped to Union lines, where they became essentially free.

articles.title: Law of the United States
articles.context: Federal law and treaties, so long as they are in accordance with the Constitution, preempt conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and in the territories. However, the scope of federal preemption is limited because the scope of federal power is not universal. In the dual-sovereign system of American federalism (actually tripartite because of the presence of Indian reservations), states are the plenary sovereigns, each with their own constitution, while the federal sovereign possesses only the limited supreme authority enumerated in the Constitution. Indeed, states may grant their citizens broader rights than the federal Constitution as long as they do not infringe on any federal constitutional rights. Thus, most U.S. law (especially the actual "living law" of contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law experienced by the majority of citizens on a day-to-day basis) consists primarily of state law, which can and does vary greatly from one state to the next.

This system consists of the federal government, state governments, and Indian reservations, each with their own powers and authorities. Federal laws and treaties, however, take precedence over state laws if there is a conflict. However, the scope of federal power is limited to what is enumerated in the Constitution, which grants state governments the authority to create their own laws and constitutional rights. Thus, the majority of American law is primarily made up of state law, which varies greatly between states.

1. According to the Law of the United States, federal laws and treaties (which must follow the Constitution) take precedence over conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and the territories. However, this supremacy is not absolute, as federal authority is not unlimited, and the states hold ultimate sovereignty.

2. The United States' federal system establishes the federal government as the supreme authority within its delegated powers as enumerated in the Constitution. Nevertheless, state constitutions are autonomous, granting citizens greater protections than the federal Constitution, albeit without infringing on federal rights. This decentralized arrangement allows states to create their own laws across various areas, including contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law, which influence the daily lives of most citizens.

3. In the dual-sovereign system of American federalism, both the federal and state governments possess supreme authority within their respective spheres, represented by the Constitution and state constitutions, respectively. As a result, federal law and treaties (subject to Constitutional limitations) supersede conflicting state and territorial laws. Still, the sovereignty of states ensures that these states can and do regulate key areas of citizens' lives, including contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law, even if state laws differ significantly from one jurisdiction to another.

American federalism offers a system of decentralized governance in which the states' constitutions are independent and empowered to grant broader rights to their citizens, as long as those rights do not infringe on federal constitutional protections. As such, state laws (including those in contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law) serve as the majority of the U.S. legal landscape, demonstrating the power of state authority in the daily lives of citizens.

While states have the power to create laws that influence their citizens' daily lives in areas such as contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law, there are limitations to the extent of such sovereignty. In such cases, federal laws and treaties, when in accordance with the Constitution, override conflicting state and territorial laws. Therefore, the majority of U.S. law in these areas is shaped by a combination of federal and state regulations.

6. Dual-sovereign federalism in the United States means that federal law and treaties, which must follow the Constitution, take precedence over conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and the territories. However, the states' limited sovereignty is still significant, as they possess the authority to grant their citizens broader rights than the federal Constitution allows. articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Law of the United States
Federal law and treaties, so long as they are in accordance with the Constitution, preempt conflicting state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S. states and in the territories. However, the scope of federal preemption is limited because the scope of federal power is not universal. In the dual-sovereign system of American federalism (actually tripartite because of the presence of Indian reservations), states are the plenary sovereigns, each with their own constitution, while the federal sovereign possesses only the limited supreme authority enumerated in the Constitution. Indeed, states may grant their citizens broader rights than the federal Constitution as long as they do not infringe on any federal constitutional rights. Thus, most U.S. law (especially the actual "living law" of contract, tort, property, criminal, and family law experienced by the majority of citizens on a day-to-day basis) consists primarily of state law, which can and does vary greatly from one state to the next.

articles.title: Geological history of Earth
articles.context: The Devonian spanned roughly from 419 to 359 Ma. The period was a time of great tectonic activity, as Laurasia and Gondwana drew closer together. The continent Euramerica (or Laurussia) was created in the early Devonian by the collision of Laurentia and Baltica, which rotated into the natural dry zone along the Tropic of Capricorn. In these near-deserts, the Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds formed, made red by the oxidized iron (hematite) characteristic of drought conditions. Near the equator Pangaea began to consolidate from the plates containing North America and Europe, further raising the northern Appalachian Mountains and forming the Caledonian Mountains in Great Britain and Scandinavia. The southern continents remained tied together in the supercontinent of Gondwana. The remainder of modern Eurasia lay in the Northern Hemisphere. Sea levels were high worldwide, and much of the land lay submerged under shallow seas. The deep, enormous Panthalassa (the "universal ocean") covered the rest of the planet. Other minor oceans were Paleo-Tethys, Proto-Tethys, Rheic Ocean and Ural Ocean (which was closed during the collision with Siberia and Baltica).

From the 8th and 6th millenniums BCE, agricultural-dependent groups started moving into the area from the north and east, most likely from the Sahara and the Sudan. In addition to their agricultural practices, these groups were also pastoralists (herders of sheep and goats).
2.2. Late-Start Neolithic Transition in Sub-Saharan Africa
The Neolithic transition in Sub-Saharan Africa occurred relatively late, beginning in the 8th and 6th millenniums BCE. During this time, agricultural-dependent groups started migrating into the region from the north and east, probably originating from the Sahara and the Sudan. In addition to adopting agriculture, these groups also engaged in pastoralism, herding sheep and goats.

The geological timeline of Earth
The geological history of Earth began with the formation of the planet itself, a process that took place over several billion years. The Devonian period, which began around 419 million years ago and ended approximately 359 million years ago, witnessed significant tectonic activity as the continents of Laurasia and Gondwana continued to converge. This collision led to the formation of the supercontinent Euramerica (or Laurussia), which encompassed present-day North America and Europe. Tectonic forces also contributed to the creation of the Appalachian Mountains and the Caledonian Mountains in the United Kingdom and Scandinavia.

During this era, significant shifts in climate occurred, leading to the development of near-desert conditions in certain areas. These arid regions gave rise to the Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds, characterized by their reddish hue due to the presence of oxidized iron, a common feature of dry environments. Meanwhile, at the equator, the formation of Pangaea was underway as the plates carrying North America and Europe gradually approached each other. This movement caused the uplift of the Appalachian Mountains and the creation of the Caledonian Mountains in Great Britain and Scandinavia.

As the Devonian progressed, the remaining portions of modern Eurasia remained primarily located in the Northern Hemisphere. Sea levels remained high, with most of the landmasses being submerged beneath shallow waters. The vast, nearly all-encompassing ocean, Panthalassa, dominated the Earth's surface. Smaller, separate oceans such as Paleo-Tethys, Proto-Tethys, Rheic Ocean, and Ural Ocean existed alongside Panthalassa, while the final stages of the Devonian saw the closure of the Ural Ocean as a result of the collision between Siberia and Baltica.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
Geological history of Earth
The Devonian spanned roughly from 419 to 359 Ma. The period was a time of great tectonic activity, as Laurasia and Gondwana drew closer together. The continent Euramerica (or Laurussia) was created in the early Devonian by the collision of Laurentia and Baltica, which rotated into the natural dry zone along the Tropic of Capricorn. In these near-deserts, the Old Red Sandstone sedimentary beds formed, made red by the oxidized iron (hematite) characteristic of drought conditions. Near the equator Pangaea began to consolidate from the plates containing North America and Europe, further raising the northern Appalachian Mountains and forming the Caledonian Mountains in Great Britain and Scandinavia. The southern continents remained tied together in the supercontinent of Gondwana. The remainder of modern Eurasia lay in the Northern Hemisphere. Sea levels were high worldwide, and much of the land lay submerged under shallow seas. The deep, enormous Panthalassa (the "universal ocean") covered the rest of the planet. Other minor oceans were Paleo-Tethys, Proto-Tethys, Rheic Ocean and Ural Ocean (which was closed during the collision with Siberia and Baltica).

completions.text:
**1. Economic Growth and the Rule of Law**

The concept of "rule of law" is particularly crucial for understanding the economic development in countries transitioning from developing to developed status. Despite its widespread usage in English-speaking nations, the precise definition of the rule of law remains elusive, even in established democracies like Sweden, Denmark, France, Germany, or Japan. A shared understanding between legal scholars from both common law and civil law systems, and those hailing from developed and developing nations alike, is vital for exploring the intricate relationship between the rule of law and the real economy.

**2. Bridging Legal Traditions for Economic Progress**

In the quest for economic advancement in developing and transitioning countries, the significance of the "rule of law" cannot be overstated. While the term has been commonly employed in English-speaking contexts, its exact interpretation remains ambiguous, even within well-established democratic societies such as Sweden, Denmark, France, Germany, or Japan. A harmonized discourse between legal experts from common law and civil law traditions, as well as from developed and developing nations, is imperative for delving into the complex ties between the rule of law and the tangible aspects of economic activity.

**3. The Rule of Law: A Universal Lens for Economic Development**

As a focal point for economic growth in developing and emerging economies, the concept of the "rule of law" plays a pivotal role. Although frequently referenced in English-speaking countries, its precise meaning remains contested, even in long-standing democracies like Sweden, Denmark, France, Germany, or Japan. An inclusive dialogue among legal professionals from diverse legal backgrounds, encompassing those from developed and developing countries, is essential for dissecting the multifaceted connections between the rule of law and the practical dimensions of the real economy.

He immediately went on the offensive, hoping to defeat the forces of Piedmont before their Austrian allies could intervene. In a series of rapid victories during the Montenotte Campaign, he knocked Piedmont out of the war in two weeks. The French then focused on the Austrians for the remainder of the war, the highlight of which became the protracted struggle for Mantua. The Austrians launched a series of offensives against the French to break the siege, but Napoleon defeated every relief effort, scoring notable victories at the battles of Castiglione, Bassano, Arcole, and Rivoli. Napoleon Bonaparte had a delightful three days of celebrations after his marriage. However, on the third day, he bid farewell to his new bride and left Paris to assume command of the Army of Italy. With an unwavering determination to vanquish the forces of Piedmont, he embarked on a daring adventure that began on Italian soil.

As the Montenotte Campaign unfurled, Napoleon rapidly achieved victory after victory, swiftly eliminating Piedmont from the war. The French forces then turned their attention towards the Austrians, sparking a heated battle that would see them face off against Napoleon's relentless tactics. 

Among Napoleon's most memorable moments was the strategically-challenging siege of Mantua. The Austrians made repeated attempts to lift the siege, but each time they were thwarted by the brilliant maneuvers of the French. Their audacious victories at Castiglione, Bassano, Arcole, and Rivoli were unparalleled, showcasing Napoleon's exceptional abilities.

The definitive French triumph at Rivoli proved to be the tipping point for the Austrians, who were left reeling from the crushing blow they suffered. The decisive victory at Rivoli signaled the demise of the Austrian presence in Italy. With a staggering 14,000 lost lives, the Austrians' war effort had been significantly weakened, while the French managed to secure their position through the loss of only 5,000 men.
  
2. Marital Obligation Vs. Command
Upon the conclusion of his marriage, Napoleon Bonaparte left Paris for Italy to assume command of the Army of Italy. This decision came at the cost of leaving behind his beloved spouse, who he would sorely miss while he was away. Napoleon knew that his temporary separation from his bride was necessary in order to fulfill his military duties.

Once in Italy, Napoleon wasted no time in setting out on a campaign of conquest. His swift actions served to quash the forces of Piedmont, leaving the Austrian alliance weakened and vulnerable. The Austrian forces would continue to make valiant efforts to break the siege of Mantua, but their attempts proved fruitless against Napoleon's growing expertise.

As Napoleon went on to win victory after victory, he established a formidable reputation on the battlefield. With each triumph, his capabilities as a military leader were more deeply entrenched in the public consciousness. The Austrian forces, defeated at Rivoli, conceded defeat and withdrew from the region, marking the end of their occupation in Italy.

The French, too, were faced with a substantial loss of life during their campaigns. The Austrians, on the other hand, saw a staggering 14,000 troops fall in battle, while the French suffered only a fraction of that loss.

3. The Napoleon Problem
A short while after Napoleon's wedding, he was forced to leave Paris and take command of the Army of Italy, against his will. The Army of Italy was in need of his assistance in fighting the forces of Piedmont and, as he left his bride behind, he began his campaign with the hope of defeating the Piedmontese.

As he entered Italy, Napoleon made swift progress and achieved quick victories against the Piedmontese forces, leaving the Austrian alliance exposed. Determined not to let the Austrians intervene and weaken the Piedmontese, Napoleon pressed on, and over time, his army became known for its formidable force.

One of Napoleon's notable accomplishments was the Siege of Mantua, which proved to be a pivotal moment in the campaign. Faced with an increasingly desperate Austrian attempt to break the siege, Napoleon managed to repel each and every attempt, driving the Austrians back with a series of daring assaults at Castiglione, Bassano, Arcole, and Rivoli.

The decisive French victory at Rivoli had a profound impact on the course of the conflict, exposing the weak state of the Austrian forces in Italy. With over 14,000 casualties amongst the Austrians and a mere 5,000 amongst the French, it was clear that Napoleon's decisive leadership had triumphed once again.

articles.title: House music
articles.context: Early house music was generally dance-based music characterized by repetitive 4/4 beats, rhythms mainly provided by drum machines, off-beat hi-hat cymbals, and synthesized basslines. While house displayed several characteristics similar to disco music, it was more electronic and minimalistic, and the repetitive rhythm of house was more important than the song itself. House music in the 2010s, while keeping several of these core elements, notably the prominent kick drum on every beat, varies widely in style and influence, ranging from the soulful and atmospheric deep house to the more minimalistic microhouse. House music has also fused with several other genres creating fusion subgenres, such as euro house, tech house, electro house and jump house.

questions.baseline_answer: House music is more electronic and dance-oriented, while Disco music is more upbeat and danceable with a focus on vocals and live instruments.
questions.adapter_answer: House music is characterized by a beat-driven, electronic, and minimalistic style, while disco music is known for its four-on-the-floor rhythm, use of synthesizers, and more complex arrangements.

questions.question: What type of music is House based on?
questions.baseline_answer: House music is based on disco music.
questions.adapter_answer: House music is based on electronic dance music.

articles.prompt:
Let's read the following passage and rewrite it in a few different ways, each one separated by a newline.

Passage:
House music
Early house music was generally dance-based music characterized by repetitive 4/4 beats, rhythms mainly provided by drum machines, off-beat hi-hat cymbals, and synthesized basslines. While house displayed several characteristics similar to disco music, it was more electronic and minimalistic, and the repetitive rhythm of house was more important than the song itself. House music in the 2010s, while keeping several of these core elements, notably the prominent kick drum on every beat, varies widely in style and influence, ranging from the soulful and atmospheric deep house to the more minimalistic microhouse. House music has also fused with several other genres creating fusion subgenres, such as euro house, tech house, electro house and jump house.

articles.title: Sexual orientation
articles.context: Most definitions of sexual orientation include a psychological component, such as the direction of an individual's erotic desires, or a behavioral component, which focuses on the sex of the individual's sexual partner/s. Some people prefer simply to follow an individual's self-definition or identity. Scientific and professional understanding is that "the core attractions that form the basis for adult sexual orientation typically emerge between middle childhood and early adolescence". Sexual orientation differs from sexual identity in that it encompasses relationships with others, while sexual identity is a concept of self.

The Army of ChÃ¢lons marched northeast towards the Belgian border to avoid the Prussians before striking south to link up with Bazaine. The Prussians, under the command of Field Marshal Count Helmuth von Moltke, took advantage of this maneuver to catch the French in a pincer grip. He left the Prussian First and Second Armies besieging Metz, except three corps detached to form the Army of the Meuse under the Crown Prince of Saxony. With this army and the Prussian Third Army, Moltke marched northward and caught up with the French at Beaumont on 30 August. After a sharp fight in which they lost 5,000 men and 40 cannons, the French withdrew toward Sedan. Having reformed in the town, the Army of ChÃ¢lons was immediately isolated by the converging Prussian armies. Napoleon III ordered the army to break out of the encirclement immediately. With MacMahon wounded on the previous day, General Auguste Ducrot took command of the French troops in the field.

- All extant mustering books have been lost or destroyed in the past.

1600: Charleston, South Carolina
The first muster in Charleston, South Carolina, was in 1600. This muster was for the establishment of the South Carolina military as a means of protecting the colony from potential Indian attacks. The 1600 mustering involved the first mustering of the South Carolina militia, which consisted of the local colonists and those brought in from other regions, such as Barbados and the Bahamas.
1707: Rhode Island
The first muster in Rhode Island was in 1707. This muster was important to establish the first Rhode Island militia in order to maintain the colony's stability and protect it from Indian raids. The mustering of 1707 primarily consisted of the local colonists who volunteered to serve in the militia.

The first muster in Connecticut was in 1715. This muster was crucial in establishing the Connecticut militia, which had been dispersed since the early 1700s. The mustering of 1715 brought together the local colonists who were willing to serve in the militia and allowed for a cohesive unit to be established.

Franco-Prussian War
With the defeat of Marshal Bazaine's Army of the Rhine at Gravelotte, the French were forced to retire to Metz, where they were besieged by over 150,000 Prussian troops of the First and Second Armies. Napoleon III and MacMahon formed the new French Army of ChÃ¢lons, to march on to Metz to rescue Bazaine. Napoleon III personally led the army with Marshal MacMahon in attendance. The Army of ChÃ¢lons marched northeast towards the Belgian border to avoid the Prussians before striking south to link up with Bazaine. The Prussians, under the command of Field Marshal Count Helmuth von Moltke, took advantage of this maneuver to catch the French in a pincer grip. He left the Prussian First and Second Armies besieging Metz, except three corps detached to form the Army of the Meuse under the Crown Prince of Saxony. With this army and the Prussian Third Army, Moltke marched northward and caught up with the French at Beaumont on 30 August. After a sharp fight in which they lost 5,000 men and 40 cannons, the French withdrew toward Sedan. Having reformed in the town, the Army of ChÃ¢lons was immediately isolated by the converging Prussian armies. Napoleon III ordered the army to break out of the encirclement immediately. With MacMahon wounded on the previous day, General Auguste Ducrot took command of the French troops in the field.

articles.title: Hunter-gatherer
articles.context: Hunter-gatherer societies manifest significant variability, depending on climate zone/life zone, available technology and societal structure. Archaeologists examine hunter-gatherer tool kits to measure variability across different groups. Collard et al. (2005) found temperature to be the only statistically significant factor to impact hunter-gatherer tool kits. Using temperature as a proxy for risk, Collard et al.'s results suggest that environments with extreme temperatures pose a threat to hunter-gatherer systems significant enough to warrant increased variability of tools. These results support Torrence's (1989) theory that risk of failure is indeed the most important factor in determining the structure of hunter-gatherer toolkits.
